</div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Obama_and_Biden_await_updates_on_bin_Laden.jpg" class="image"><img alt="President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden, along with members of the national security team, receive an update on Operation Neptune's Spear, a mission against Osama bin Laden, in one of the conference rooms of the Situation Room of the White House, on May 1, 2011. They are watching live feed from drones operating over the bin Laden complex." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Obama_and_Biden_await_updates_on_bin_Laden.jpg/220px-Obama_and_Biden_await_updates_on_bin_Laden.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Obama_and_Biden_await_updates_on_bin_Laden.jpg/330px-Obama_and_Biden_await_updates_on_bin_Laden.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Obama_and_Biden_await_updates_on_bin_Laden.jpg/440px-Obama_and_Biden_await_updates_on_bin_Laden.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4096" data-file-height="2731" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Obama_and_Biden_await_updates_on_bin_Laden.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Obama and members of the national security team receive an update on <a href="/wiki/Operation_Neptune%27s_Spear" class="mw-redirect" title="Operation Neptune's Spear">Operation Neptune's Spear</a> in the <a href="/wiki/White_House_Situation_Room" class="mw-redirect" title="White House Situation Room">White House Situation Room</a>, May 1, 2011. See also: <a href="/wiki/Situation_Room_(photograph)" title="Situation Room (photograph)"><i>Situation Room</i></a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Starting with information received from Central Intelligence Agency operatives in July 2010, the CIA developed intelligence over the next several months that determined what they believed to be the hideout of <a href="/wiki/Osama_bin_Laden" title="Osama bin Laden">Osama bin Laden</a>. He was living in seclusion in <a href="/wiki/Osama_bin_Laden%27s_compound_in_Abbottabad" title="Osama bin Laden's compound in Abbottabad">a large compound</a> in <a href="/wiki/Abbottabad" title="Abbottabad">Abbottabad</a>, Pakistan, a suburban area 35 miles (56&#160;km) from <a href="/wiki/Islamabad" title="Islamabad">Islamabad</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT-clues_389-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-clues-389">[389]</a></sup> CIA head <a href="/wiki/Leon_Panetta" title="Leon Panetta">Leon Panetta</a> reported this intelligence to President Obama in March 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT-clues_389-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-clues-389">[389]</a></sup> Meeting with his national security advisers over the course of the next six weeks, Obama rejected a plan to bomb the compound, and authorized a "surgical raid" to be conducted by <a href="/wiki/United_States_Navy_SEALs" title="United States Navy SEALs">United States Navy SEALs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT-clues_389-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-clues-389">[389]</a></sup> The operation took place on May 1, 2011, and resulted in the shooting death of bin Laden and the seizure of papers, computer drives and disks from the compound.<sup id="cite_ref-WP-binLaden_390-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WP-binLaden-390">[390]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ND-binLaden_391-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ND-binLaden-391">[391]</a></sup> DNA testing was one of five methods used to positively identify bin Laden's corpse,<sup id="cite_ref-ABC-binLaden_392-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ABC-binLaden-392">[392]</a></sup> which was buried at sea several hours later.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT-ObamaAnnounce_393-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-ObamaAnnounce-393">[393]</a></sup> Within minutes of the President's announcement from Washington, DC, late in the evening on May 1, there were spontaneous celebrations around the country as crowds gathered outside the White House, and at New York City's <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_site" title="World Trade Center site">Ground Zero</a> and <a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">Times Square</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-WP-binLaden_390-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WP-binLaden-390">[390]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Guard-ObamaAnnounce_394-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guard-ObamaAnnounce-394">[394]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Reactions_to_the_death_of_Osama_bin_Laden" title="Reactions to the death of Osama bin Laden">Reaction to the announcement</a> was positive across party lines, including from former presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush,<sup id="cite_ref-Bloom-binLaden_395-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bloom-binLaden-395">[395]</a></sup> and from many countries around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-NPR-worldreaction_396-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NPR-worldreaction-396">[396]</a></sup></p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Iran_nuclear_talks">Iran nuclear talks</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_talks_with_Benjamin_Netanyahu_(8637772147).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Barack_Obama_talks_with_Benjamin_Netanyahu_%288637772147%29.jpg/220px-Barack_Obama_talks_with_Benjamin_Netanyahu_%288637772147%29.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Barack_Obama_talks_with_Benjamin_Netanyahu_%288637772147%29.jpg/330px-Barack_Obama_talks_with_Benjamin_Netanyahu_%288637772147%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Barack_Obama_talks_with_Benjamin_Netanyahu_%288637772147%29.jpg/440px-Barack_Obama_talks_with_Benjamin_Netanyahu_%288637772147%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4096" data-file-height="2730" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_talks_with_Benjamin_Netanyahu_(8637772147).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Obama talks with Benjamin Netanyahu, March 2013</div>
</div>
</div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Joint_Comprehensive_Plan_of_Action" title="Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action">Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action</a></div>
<p>In November 2013, Obama's administration opened <a href="/wiki/Negotiations_leading_to_the_Joint_Comprehensive_Plan_of_Action" title="Negotiations leading to the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action">negotiations</a> with Iran to prevent it from acquiring <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapon" title="Nuclear weapon">nuclear weapons</a>, which included an <a href="/wiki/Joint_Plan_of_Action" title="Joint Plan of Action">interim agreement</a>. Negotiations took two years with numerous delays, with a deal being announced July 14, 2015. The deal, titled the "<a href="/wiki/Joint_Comprehensive_Plan_of_Action" title="Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action">Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action</a>", saw the removal of sanctions in exchange for measures that would prevent Iran from producing nuclear weapons. While Obama hailed the agreement as being a step towards a more hopeful world, the deal drew strong criticism from Republican and conservative quarters, and from Israeli prime minister <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Netanyahu" title="Benjamin Netanyahu">Benjamin Netanyahu</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">[397]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">[398]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">[399]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Relations_with_Cuba">Relations with Cuba</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Cuban_Thaw" class="mw-redirect" title="United States–Cuban Thaw">United States–Cuban Thaw</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Handshake_between_the_President_and_Cuban_President_Ra%C3%BAl_Castro.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Handshake_between_the_President_and_Cuban_President_Ra%C3%BAl_Castro.jpg/220px-Handshake_between_the_President_and_Cuban_President_Ra%C3%BAl_Castro.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Handshake_between_the_President_and_Cuban_President_Ra%C3%BAl_Castro.jpg/330px-Handshake_between_the_President_and_Cuban_President_Ra%C3%BAl_Castro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Handshake_between_the_President_and_Cuban_President_Ra%C3%BAl_Castro.jpg/440px-Handshake_between_the_President_and_Cuban_President_Ra%C3%BAl_Castro.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1000" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Handshake_between_the_President_and_Cuban_President_Ra%C3%BAl_Castro.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Obama meeting with Cuban President <a href="/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_Castro" title="Raúl Castro">Raúl Castro</a> in Panama, April 2015</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Since the spring of 2013, secret meetings were conducted between the United States and Cuba in the neutral locations of Canada and <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">[400]</a></sup> The Vatican first became involved in 2013 when <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Pope Francis</a> advised the U.S. and Cuba to <a href="/wiki/Prisoner_exchange" title="Prisoner exchange">exchange prisoners</a> as a gesture of goodwill.<sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">[401]</a></sup> On December 10, 2013, Cuban President <a href="/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_Castro" title="Raúl Castro">Raúl Castro</a>, in a significant public moment, greeted and shook hands with Obama at the <a href="/wiki/Death_of_Nelson_Mandela" title="Death of Nelson Mandela">Nelson Mandela memorial service</a> in <a href="/wiki/Johannesburg" title="Johannesburg">Johannesburg</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">[402]</a></sup></p>
<p>In December 2014, after the secret meetings, it was announced that Obama, with <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Pope Francis</a> as an intermediary, had negotiated a restoration of relations with Cuba, after nearly sixty years of détente.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">[403]</a></sup> Popularly dubbed the <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Thaw" title="Cuban Thaw">Cuban Thaw</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_Republic" title="The New Republic">The New Republic</a></i> deemed the Cuban Thaw to be "Obama's finest foreign policy achievement."<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">[404]</a></sup> On July 1, 2015, President Barack Obama announced that formal diplomatic relations between Cuba and the United States would resume, and embassies would be opened in Washington and <a href="/wiki/Havana" title="Havana">Havana</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[405]</a></sup> The countries' respective "interests sections" in one another's capitals were upgraded to embassies on July 20 and August 13, 2015, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[406]</a></sup></p>
<p>Obama visited Havana, Cuba for two days in March 2016, becoming the first sitting U.S. President to arrive since <a href="/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge" title="Calvin Coolidge">Calvin Coolidge</a> in 1928.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[407]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Africa">Africa</span></h4>
<p>Obama spoke in front of the <a href="/wiki/African_Union" title="African Union">African Union</a> in <a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a>, Ethiopia, on July 29, 2015, the first sitting U.S. president to do so. He gave a speech encouraging the world to increase economic ties via investments and trade with the continent, and lauded the progresses made in <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Africa" title="Education in Africa">education</a>, infrastructure, and <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Africa" title="Economy of Africa">economy</a>. He also criticized the lack of democracy and leaders who refuse to step aside, discrimination against minorities (<a href="/wiki/LGBT" title="LGBT">LGBT</a> people, religious groups and ethnicities), and corruption. He suggested an intensified <a href="/wiki/Democratization" title="Democratization">democratization</a> and free trade, to significantly improve the quality of life for Africans.<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">[408]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">[409]</a></sup> During his July 2015 trip, Obama also was the first U.S. president ever to <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_visits_to_Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="United States presidential visits to Sub-Saharan Africa">visit</a> Kenya, which is the homeland of his father.<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">[410]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Hiroshima_speech">Hiroshima speech</span></h4>
<p>On May 27, 2016, 2½ months before the 71st anniversary of <a href="/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki" title="Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki">the U.S. atomic bombing of Hiroshima</a> that ended <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, Obama became the first sitting American president to visit <a href="/wiki/Hiroshima" title="Hiroshima">Hiroshima</a>, Japan. Accompanied by Japanese Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Shinz%C5%8D_Abe" title="Shinzō Abe">Shinzo Abe</a>, Obama paid tribute to the victims of the bombing at the <a href="/wiki/Hiroshima_Peace_Memorial_Museum" title="Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum">Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">[411]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Russia">Russia</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Obama_meeting_with_Trump_2_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Obama_meeting_with_Trump_2_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Obama_meeting_with_Trump_2_%28cropped%29.jpg" width="220" height="170" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Obama_meeting_with_Trump_2_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Obama_meeting_with_Trump_2_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Obama_meeting_with_Trump_2_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-Obama_meeting_with_Trump_2_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="676" data-file-height="523" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Obama_meeting_with_Trump_2_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Obama meets with President-elect <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> at the White House, November 10, 2016.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93United_States_relations#Obama.27s_tenure_.282009.E2.80.932017.29" title="Russia–United States relations">Russia–United States relations §&#160;Obama's tenure (2009–2017)</a></div>
<p>After <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">Russia's invasion of Crimea</a> in 2014, <a href="/wiki/Russian_military_intervention_in_Syria" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian military intervention in Syria">military intervention</a> in Syria in 2015, and the <a href="/wiki/2016_United_States_election_interference_by_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="2016 United States election interference by Russia">interference in the 2016 presidential election</a><sup id="cite_ref-ftelect_412-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ftelect-412">[412]</a></sup> in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2016" title="United States presidential election, 2016">2016 U.S. presidential election</a>, Obama's Russia policy was widely seen as a failure.<sup id="cite_ref-friedmnyt_413-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-friedmnyt-413">[413]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/George_Robertson,_Baron_Robertson_of_Port_Ellen" title="George Robertson, Baron Robertson of Port Ellen">George Robertson</a>, a former UK defense secretary and NATO secretary-general, said that Obama had "allowed Putin to jump back on the world stage and test the resolve of the West", adding that the legacy of this disaster would last.<sup id="cite_ref-obexit_414-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-obexit-414">[414]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cultural_and_political_image">Cultural and political image</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Public_image_of_Barack_Obama" title="Public image of Barack Obama">Public image of Barack Obama</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/International_reaction_to_the_United_States_presidential_election,_2008" class="mw-redirect" title="International reaction to the United States presidential election, 2008">International reaction to the United States presidential election, 2008</a> and <a href="/wiki/International_reactions_to_the_United_States_presidential_election,_2012" title="International reactions to the United States presidential election, 2012">International reactions to the United States presidential election, 2012</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Official_portrait_of_Barack_Obama.jpg" class="image"><img alt="First official presidential portrait of Barack Obama, wearing a black suit with a blue tie and American flag lapel pin, indoors with the American flag and the flag of the President draped in the background" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Official_portrait_of_Barack_Obama.jpg/170px-Official_portrait_of_Barack_Obama.jpg" width="170" height="231" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Official_portrait_of_Barack_Obama.jpg/255px-Official_portrait_of_Barack_Obama.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Official_portrait_of_Barack_Obama.jpg/340px-Official_portrait_of_Barack_Obama.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1916" data-file-height="2608" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Official_portrait_of_Barack_Obama.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Obama's first term presidential portrait (2009)</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Obama's family history, upbringing, and <a href="/wiki/Ivy_League" title="Ivy League">Ivy League</a> education differ markedly from those of African-American politicians who launched their careers in the 1960s through participation in the <a href="/wiki/Civil_rights_movement" class="mw-redirect" title="Civil rights movement">civil rights movement</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[415]</a></sup> Expressing puzzlement over questions about whether he is "black enough", Obama told an August 2007 meeting of the <a href="/wiki/National_Association_of_Black_Journalists" title="National Association of Black Journalists">National Association of Black Journalists</a> that "we're still locked in this notion that if you appeal to white folks then there must be something wrong."<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[416]</a></sup> Obama acknowledged his youthful image in an October 2007 campaign speech, saying: "I wouldn't be here if, time and again, the torch had not been passed to a new generation."<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[417]</a></sup></p>
<p>Obama is frequently referred to as an exceptional orator.<sup id="cite_ref-exceptional_orator_418-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-exceptional_orator-418">[418]</a></sup> During his pre-inauguration transition period and continuing into his presidency, Obama has delivered a series of weekly Internet video addresses.<sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">[419]</a></sup> Former presidential campaign surrogate and Georgetown professor, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Eric_Dyson" title="Michael Eric Dyson">Michael Eric Dyson</a>, is both critical and sympathetic of President Obama's leadership in race relations, indicating that Obama's speeches and action on racial disparity and justice have been somewhat reactive and reluctant when, especially in the later part of his second term, racial violence demanded immediate presidential action and conversation.<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">[420]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gallup_Poll-Approval_Rating-Barack_Obama.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Gallup_Poll-Approval_Rating-Barack_Obama.svg/220px-Gallup_Poll-Approval_Rating-Barack_Obama.svg.png" width="220" height="118" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Gallup_Poll-Approval_Rating-Barack_Obama.svg/330px-Gallup_Poll-Approval_Rating-Barack_Obama.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Gallup_Poll-Approval_Rating-Barack_Obama.svg/440px-Gallup_Poll-Approval_Rating-Barack_Obama.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="650" data-file-height="349" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Gallup_Poll-Approval_Rating-Barack_Obama.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Presidential Approval Ratings</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Gallup_Organization" class="mw-redirect" title="Gallup Organization">Gallup Organization</a>, Obama began his presidency with a 68% approval rating<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[421]</a></sup> before gradually declining for the rest of the year, and eventually bottoming out at 41% in August 2010,<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">[422]</a></sup> a trend similar to <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a>'s and <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a>'s first years in office.<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">[423]</a></sup> He experienced a small poll bounce shortly after the <a href="/wiki/Death_of_Osama_bin_Laden" title="Death of Osama bin Laden">death of Osama bin Laden</a> on May 2, 2011. This bounce lasted until around June 2011, when his approval numbers dropped back to where they were previously.<sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">[424]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">[425]</a></sup> His approval ratings rebounded around the same time as his reelection in 2012, with polls showing an average job approval of 52% shortly after his second inauguration.<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[426]</a></sup> Despite approval ratings dropping to 39% in late-2013 due to the ACA roll-out, they climbed to 50% in January 2015 according to Gallup.<sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427">[427]</a></sup></p>
<p>Polls showed strong support for Obama in other countries both before and during his presidency.<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428">[428]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[429]</a></sup> In a February 2009 poll conducted in Western Europe and the U.S. by <a href="/wiki/Harris_Interactive" class="mw-redirect" title="Harris Interactive">Harris Interactive</a> for <a href="/wiki/France_24" title="France 24">France 24</a> and the <i><a href="/wiki/International_Herald_Tribune" class="mw-redirect" title="International Herald Tribune">International Herald Tribune</a></i>, Obama was rated as the most respected world leader, as well as the most powerful.<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">[430]</a></sup> In a similar poll conducted by Harris in May 2009, Obama was rated as the most popular world leader, as well as the one figure most people would pin their hopes on for pulling the world out of the economic downturn.<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">[431]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">[432]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:G8_leaders_watching_football.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Prime Minister David Cameron of the United Kingdom, President Barack Obama, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, José Manuel Barroso, President of the European Commission, President François Hollande of France and others react emotionally while watching the overtime shootout of the Chelsea vs. Bayern Munich Champions League final, in the Laurel Cabin conference room during the G8 Summit at Camp David, Maryland, May 19, 2012. Cameron raises his arms triumphantly as the Chelsea team wins their first Champions League title in the overtime shootout." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/G8_leaders_watching_football.jpg/220px-G8_leaders_watching_football.jpg" width="220" height="144" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/G8_leaders_watching_football.jpg/330px-G8_leaders_watching_football.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/G8_leaders_watching_football.jpg/440px-G8_leaders_watching_football.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4021" data-file-height="2629" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:G8_leaders_watching_football.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
G8 leaders watching the <a href="/wiki/2012_UEFA_Champions_League_Final" title="2012 UEFA Champions League Final">2012 UEFA Champions League Final</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Obama won <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Spoken_Word_Album" title="Grammy Award for Best Spoken Word Album">Best Spoken Word Album</a> <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award" title="Grammy Award">Grammy Awards</a> for abridged <a href="/wiki/Audiobook" title="Audiobook">audiobook</a> versions of <i><a href="/wiki/Dreams_from_My_Father" title="Dreams from My Father">Dreams from My Father</a></i> in February 2006 and for <i><a href="/wiki/The_Audacity_of_Hope" title="The Audacity of Hope">The Audacity of Hope</a></i> in February 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[433]</a></sup> His <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama_presidential_primary_campaign,_2008#New_Hampshire" title="Barack Obama presidential primary campaign, 2008">concession speech</a> after the New Hampshire primary was set to music by independent artists as the music video "<a href="/wiki/Yes_We_Can_(will.i.am_song)" title="Yes We Can (will.i.am song)">Yes We Can</a>", which was viewed 10&#160;million times on YouTube in its first month<sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">[434]</a></sup> and received a <a href="/wiki/Daytime_Emmy_Award" title="Daytime Emmy Award">Daytime Emmy Award</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">[435]</a></sup> In December 2008 and in 2012, <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> magazine named Obama as its <a href="/wiki/Time_Person_of_the_Year" title="Time Person of the Year">Person of the Year</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">[436]</a></sup> The 2008 awarding was for his historic candidacy and election, which <i>Time</i> described as "the steady march of seemingly impossible accomplishments".<sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">[437]</a></sup> On May 25, 2011, Obama became the first President of the United States to address both houses of the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Parliament of the United Kingdom">UK Parliament</a> in <a href="/wiki/Westminster_Hall" class="mw-redirect" title="Westminster Hall">Westminster Hall</a>, London. This was only the fifth occurrence since the start of the 20th century, of a head of state being extended this invitation, following <a href="/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle" title="Charles de Gaulle">Charles de Gaulle</a> in 1960, <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Mandela" title="Nelson Mandela">Nelson Mandela</a> in 1996, <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_II" title="Elizabeth II">Queen Elizabeth II</a> in 2002 and <a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XVI" title="Pope Benedict XVI">Pope Benedict XVI</a> in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438">[438]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">[439]</a></sup></p>
<p>On October 9, 2009, the <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Nobel_Committee" title="Norwegian Nobel Committee">Norwegian Nobel Committee</a> announced that Obama had won the <a href="/wiki/2009_Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="2009 Nobel Peace Prize">2009 Nobel Peace Prize</a> "for his extraordinary efforts to strengthen international diplomacy and cooperation between peoples".<sup id="cite_ref-nobel_peace_prize_440-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nobel_peace_prize-440">[440]</a></sup> Obama accepted this award in <a href="/wiki/Oslo" title="Oslo">Oslo</a>, Norway on December 10, 2009, with "deep gratitude and great humility."<sup id="cite_ref-CNN:_Obama_acceptance_transcript_441-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNN:_Obama_acceptance_transcript-441">[441]</a></sup> The award drew a mixture of praise and criticism from world leaders and media figures.<sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442">[442]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">[443]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">[444]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-445" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-445">[445]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446">[446]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447">[447]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-whr1_448-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-whr1-448">[448]</a></sup> Obama's peace prize was called a "stunning surprise" by <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-449" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-449">[449]</a></sup> Obama is the fourth U.S. president to be awarded the Nobel Peace Prize and the third to become a Nobel laureate while in office.<sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450">[450]</a></sup> Obama's Nobel Prize has been viewed skeptically in subsequent years, especially after the director of the Nobel Institute, <a href="/wiki/Geir_Lundestad" title="Geir Lundestad">Geir Lundestad</a>, said Obama's Peace Prize did not have the desired effect.<sup id="cite_ref-451" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-451">[451]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-presidency">Post-presidency</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_at_Trump_inauguration.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Barack_Obama_at_Trump_inauguration.jpg/220px-Barack_Obama_at_Trump_inauguration.jpg" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Barack_Obama_at_Trump_inauguration.jpg/330px-Barack_Obama_at_Trump_inauguration.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Barack_Obama_at_Trump_inauguration.jpg/440px-Barack_Obama_at_Trump_inauguration.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2911" data-file-height="1934" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_at_Trump_inauguration.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Obama at Trump inauguration on January 20, 2017</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Barack Obama's presidency ended at noon on January 20, 2017, immediately following the <a href="/wiki/Inauguration_of_Donald_Trump" title="Inauguration of Donald Trump">inauguration</a> of his Republican successor, <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a>. After the inauguration, Obama lifted off on <a href="/wiki/Executive_One" title="Executive One">Executive One</a>, circled the White House, and flew to <a href="/wiki/Joint_Base_Andrews" title="Joint Base Andrews">Joint Base Andrews</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-452" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-452">[452]</a></sup> The family rented a house in <a href="/wiki/Kalorama,_Washington,_D.C." title="Kalorama, Washington, D.C.">Kalorama, Washington, D.C.</a><sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453">[453]</a></sup></p>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_National_Committee_chairmanship_election,_2017" title="Democratic National Committee chairmanship election, 2017">2017 Democratic National Committee chairmanship election</a>, the Obama administration pushed for Tom Perez to run against Keith Ellison and President Barack Obama personally called DNC members to vote for Perez.<sup id="cite_ref-454" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-454">[454]</a></sup></p>
<p>On March 2, 2017, the <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_Presidential_Library_and_Museum" title="John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum">John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum</a> awarded the annual <a href="/wiki/Profile_in_Courage_Award" title="Profile in Courage Award">Profile in Courage Award</a> to Obama "for his enduring commitment to democratic ideals and elevating the standard of political courage."<sup id="cite_ref-455" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-455">[455]</a></sup></p>
<p>On April 24, 2017, in his first public appearance out of office, Obama appeared at a seminar at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Chicago" title="University of Chicago">University of Chicago</a> aimed at the engagement with a new generation as well as an appeal for their participation in politics.<sup id="cite_ref-456" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-456">[456]</a></sup></p>
<p>On May 4, 2017, three days ahead of the <a href="/wiki/French_presidential_election,_2017" title="French presidential election, 2017">French presidential election</a>, Obama endorsed <a href="/wiki/Emmanuel_Macron" title="Emmanuel Macron">Emmanuel Macron</a>: "He appeals to people’s hopes and not their fears, and I enjoyed speaking to Emmanuel recently to hear about his independent movement and his vision for the future of France."<sup id="cite_ref-457" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-457">[457]</a></sup> Macron went on to win the election.</p>
<p>On May 9, 2017, Obama delivered a speech urging for election participation and research during a food innovation summit in <a href="/wiki/Milan,_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Milan, Italy">Milan, Italy</a>, saying in part, "if you don't vote and you don't pay attention, you'll get policies that don't reflect your interest."<sup id="cite_ref-458" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-458">[458]</a></sup></p>
<p>While in <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a> on May 25, Obama made a joint public appearance with Chancellor Merkel where he stressed inclusion and for leaders to question themselves, Obama having been formally invited to Berlin while still in office as part of an effort to boost Merkel's re-election campaign.<sup id="cite_ref-459" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-459">[459]</a></sup></p>
<p>Obama traveled to <a href="/wiki/Kensington_Palace" title="Kensington Palace">Kensington Palace</a> in <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a> and met with <a href="/wiki/Prince_Harry" title="Prince Harry">Prince Harry</a> on May 27, 2017; Obama tweeted afterward that the two discussed their foundations and offering condolences in the wake of the <a href="/wiki/2017_Manchester_Arena_bombing" title="2017 Manchester Arena bombing">Manchester Arena bombing</a> that occurred five days prior.<sup id="cite_ref-460" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-460">[460]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Presidential_library">Presidential library</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama_Presidential_Center" title="Barack Obama Presidential Center">Barack Obama Presidential Center</a></div>
<p>The Obama Presidential Center is the planned <a href="/wiki/Presidential_library" title="Presidential library">presidential library</a> of Barack Obama. The center will be hosted by the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Chicago" title="University of Chicago">University of Chicago</a>, and will be located in <a href="/wiki/Jackson_Park_(Chicago)" title="Jackson Park (Chicago)">Jackson Park</a> on the <a href="/wiki/South_Side,_Chicago" title="South Side, Chicago">South Side</a> of Chicago, Illinois. Once completed, it will become the 14th site in the <a href="/wiki/National_Archives_and_Records_Administration" title="National Archives and Records Administration">National Archives and Records Administration</a>'s presidential library system.<sup id="cite_ref-461" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-461">[461]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span></h2>
<p>Obama's most significant legacy is generally considered to be the <a href="/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act" title="Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act">Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act</a>, provisions of which went into effect from 2010 to 2020. Together with the <a href="/wiki/Health_Care_and_Education_Reconciliation_Act" class="mw-redirect" title="Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act">Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act</a> amendment, it represents the most significant regulatory overhaul of the <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_the_United_States" title="Health care in the United States">U.S. healthcare system</a> since the passage of <a href="/wiki/Medicare_(United_States)" title="Medicare (United States)">Medicare</a> and <a href="/wiki/Medicaid" title="Medicaid">Medicaid</a> in 1965.<sup id="cite_ref-legacy_462-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-legacy-462">[462]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Job_Growth_by_U.S._President_-_v1.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Job_Growth_by_U.S._President_-_v1.png/250px-Job_Growth_by_U.S._President_-_v1.png" width="250" height="151" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Job_Growth_by_U.S._President_-_v1.png/375px-Job_Growth_by_U.S._President_-_v1.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Job_Growth_by_U.S._President_-_v1.png/500px-Job_Growth_by_U.S._President_-_v1.png 2x" data-file-width="1093" data-file-height="661" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Job_Growth_by_U.S._President_-_v1.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Job growth during the presidency of Obama compared to predecessors, as measured as cumulative percentage change from month after inauguration to end of term.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Many commentators credit Obama with averting a threatened depression and pulling the country out of the so-called "<a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">Great Recession</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-legacy_462-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-legacy-462">[462]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Bureau_of_Labor_Statistics" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics">U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Obama_administration" class="mw-redirect" title="Obama administration">Obama administration</a> created 11.3 million jobs from the month after the <a href="/wiki/First_inauguration_of_Barack_Obama" title="First inauguration of Barack Obama">first inauguration of Barack Obama</a> to the end of his term.<sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463">[463]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 2010, President Obama signed into effect the <a href="/wiki/Dodd%E2%80%93Frank_Wall_Street_Reform_and_Consumer_Protection_Act" title="Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act">Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act</a>. Passed as a response to the <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%9308" class="mw-redirect" title="Financial crisis of 2007–08">financial crisis of 2007–08</a>, it brought the most significant changes to <a href="/wiki/Financial_regulation" title="Financial regulation">financial regulation</a> in the United States since the regulatory reform that followed the <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">Great Depression</a> under Democratic President <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-464" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-464">[464]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 2011, the <a href="/wiki/Don%27t_Ask,_Don%27t_Tell_Repeal_Act_of_2010" title="Don't Ask, Don't Tell Repeal Act of 2010">Don't Ask, Don't Tell Repeal Act of 2010</a> went into effect, bringing an end to "<a href="/wiki/Don%27t_ask,_don%27t_tell" title="Don't ask, don't tell">don't ask, don't tell</a>" policy in the US armed forces that banned open service from <a href="/wiki/Lesbian,_gay_and_bisexual" class="mw-redirect" title="Lesbian, gay and bisexual">LGB</a> people. Obama succeeded in allowing open military service for LGB people in the US armed forces where his Democratic predecessor, US President Bill Clinton, had failed to do so; the <a href="/wiki/Clinton_administration" class="mw-redirect" title="Clinton administration">Clinton administration</a> having instead enacted the compromise "don't ask, don't tell" policy. In 2016, the <a href="/wiki/Obama_administration" class="mw-redirect" title="Obama administration">Obama administration</a> brought an end to the ban on <a href="/wiki/Transgender" title="Transgender">transgender</a> people serving openly in the US armed forces.<sup id="cite_ref-465" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-465">[465]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-TransBan1_215-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TransBan1-215">[215]</a></sup></p>
<p>President Obama continued the <a href="/wiki/Drone_strikes" class="mw-redirect" title="Drone strikes">drone strikes</a> that President <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> started during his presidency in <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Somalia" title="Somalia">Somalia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a>. Obama also ordered drone strikes in <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">Libya</a> in 2011, the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a> in 2012, and <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a> in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-466" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-466">[466]</a></sup> Obama left about 9,800 US troops in <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, 5,262 US troops in Iraq, 503 US troops in Syria, 133 US troops in Pakistan, 106 US troops in Somalia, 7 US troops in Yemen, and 2 US troops in Libya at the end of his presidency.<sup id="cite_ref-467" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-467">[467]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-468" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-468">[468]</a></sup></p>
<p>According to <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research Center</a> and <a href="/wiki/United_States_Bureau_of_Justice_Statistics" class="mw-redirect" title="United States Bureau of Justice Statistics">United States Bureau of Justice Statistics</a>, from December 31, 2009 to December 31, 2015, that inmates sentenced in US federal custody declined by 5% under US President Obama. This is the largest decline in sentenced inmates in US federal custody since Democrat US President <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Carter" title="Jimmy Carter">Jimmy Carter</a>. By contrast, the federal prison population increased significantly under US president Ronald Reagan, George H. W. Bush, Bill Clinton, and George W. Bush.<sup id="cite_ref-469" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-469">[469]</a></sup></p>
<p>A 2017 <a href="/wiki/C-SPAN" title="C-SPAN">C-SPAN</a> Presidential Historians Survey ranked Obama as the 12th best US president.<sup id="cite_ref-470" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-470">[470]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-471" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-471">[471]</a></sup></p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes_and_references">Notes and references</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h3>
<div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: decimal;">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-Merriam-Webster_Dictionary-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Merriam-Webster_Dictionary_1-0">^</a></b></span>
<ul>
<li><span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/Barak">"Barak"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Merriam-Webster" title="Merriam-Webster">Merriam-Webster Dictionary</a></i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABarack+Obama&amp;rft.atitle=Barak&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.merriam-webster.com%2Fdictionary%2FBarak&amp;rft.jtitle=Merriam-Webster+Dictionary&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>

<li><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/Obama">"Obama"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Merriam-Webster" title="Merriam-Webster">Merriam-Webster Dictionary</a></i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABarack+Obama&amp;rft.atitle=Obama&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.merriam-webster.com%2Fdictionary%2FObama&amp;rft.jtitle=Merriam-Webster+Dictionary&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></li>
</ul>
</li>

<li><cite class="citation news">Seelye, Katharine Q. <li id="cite_note-Trinity-85"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Trinity_85-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">Garrett, Major; Obama, Barack (March 14, 2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2008/03/obama_talks_to_major_garrett_o.html">"Obama talks to Major Garrett on 'Hannity &amp; Colmes<span style="padding-right:0.2em;">'</span>"</a>. RealClearPolitics<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">November 10,</span> 2012</span>. <q>Major Garrett, Fox News correspondent: So the first question, how long have you been a member in good standing of that church? Sen. Barack Obama (D-IL), presidential candidate: You know, I've been a member since 1991 or '92. And&#160;– but I have known Trinity even before then when I was a community organizer on the South Side, helping steel workers find jobs&#160;... Garrett: As a member in good standing, were you a regular attendee of Sunday services? Obama: You know, I won't say that I was a perfect attendee. I was regular in spurts, because there was times when, for example, our child had just been born, our first child. And so we didn't go as regularly then.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABarack+Obama&amp;rft.atitle=Obama+talks+to+Major+Garrett+on+%27Hannity+%26+Colmes%27&amp;rft.aufirst=Major&amp;rft.aulast=Garrett&amp;rft.au=Obama%2C+Barack&amp;rft.date=2008-03-14&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.realclearpolitics.com%2Farticles%2F2008%2F03%2Fobama_talks_to_major_garrett_o.html&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-92"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-92">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation magazine">Obama, Barack (August–September 1988). "Why organize? Problems and promise in the inner city". <i>Illinois Issues</i>. Vol.&#160;14 no.&#160;8–9. pp.&#160;40–42. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number" title="International Standard Serial Number">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0738-9663">0738-9663</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABarack+Obama&amp;rft.au=Obama%2C+Barack&amp;rft.btitle=Why+organize%3F+Problems+and+promise+in+the+inner+city&amp;rft.date=1988-08%2F1988-09&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.issn=0738-9663&amp;rft.pages=40-42&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span> reprinted in:<br />

Springfield, IL: Sangamon State University. pp.&#160;35–40. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-9620873-3-5" title="Special:BookSources/0-9620873-3-5">0-9620873-3-5</a>. <q>He has also been a consultant and instructor for the Gamaliel Foundation, an organizing institute working throughout the Midwest.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABarack+Obama&amp;rft.btitle=After+Alinsky%3A+community+organizing+in+Illinois&amp;rft.date=1990&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=0-9620873-3-5&amp;rft.pages=35-40&amp;rft.place=Springfield%2C+IL&amp;rft.pub=Sangamon+State+University&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Obama_2012-93"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Obama_2012_93-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Obama, Auma (2012). <i>And then life happens: a memoir</i>. New York: St. Martin's Press. pp.&#160;189–208, 212–216. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-250-01005-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-250-01005-6">978-1-250-01005-6</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABarack+Obama&amp;rft.aufirst=Auma&amp;rft.aulast=Obama&amp;rft.btitle=And+then+life+happens%3A+a+memoir&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-250-01005-6&amp;rft.pages=189-208%2C+212-216&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=St.+Martin%27s+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-94"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-94">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Obama (1995, 2004), pp. 299–437.</span>
<ul>
<li><span class="reference-text">Maraniss (2012), pp. 564–570.</span></li>

Bureau of Labor Statistics. <b>134</b> (3): 23–32. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">March 11,</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABarack+Obama&amp;rft.atitle=Total+Scores%2FOverall+Rankings&amp;rft.date=2017&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.c-span.org%2Fpresidentsurvey2017%2F%3Fpage%3Doverall&amp;rft.jtitle=Presidential+Historians+Survey&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-471"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-471">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">Von Drehle, David (February 17, 2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://time.com/4674300/cspan-presidents-rank-2017/">"Barack Obama Ranked 12th Best U.S. President Ever in Major Survey of Historians"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">February 18,</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABarack+Obama&amp;rft.atitle=Barack+Obama+Ranked+12th+Best+U.S.+President+Ever+in+Major+Survey+of+Historians&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.aulast=Von+Drehle&amp;rft.date=2017-02-17&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4674300%2Fcspan-presidents-rank-2017%2F&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
</ol>
</div>

<td style="width:30%;" rowspan="1">Preceded&#160;by<br />
<span style="font-weight: bold"><a href="/wiki/Nicolas_Sarkozy" title="Nicolas Sarkozy">Nicolas Sarkozy</a></span></td>
<td style="width: 40%; text-align: center;" rowspan="1"><b>Chair of the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_Eight" title="Group of Eight">Group of Eight</a></b><br />
2012</td>
<td style="width: 30%; text-align: center;" rowspan="1">Succeeded&#160;by<br />
<span style="font-weight: bold"><a href="/wiki/David_Cameron" title="David Cameron">David Cameron</a></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th colspan="3" style="border-top: 5px solid #ccffcc;"><a href="/wiki/United_States_order_of_precedence" title="United States order of precedence">United States order of precedence</a> (ceremonial)</th>
</tr>
<tr style="text-align:center;">
<td style="width:30%;" rowspan="1">Preceded&#160;by<br />
<span style="font-weight: bold"><a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a></span><br />
<small><i><b>as Former President</b></i></small></td>
<td style="width: 40%; text-align: center;" rowspan="1"><b><a href="/wiki/United_States_order_of_precedence" title="United States order of precedence">Order of Precedence of the United States</a><br />
<i><small>Former President</small></i></b></td>
<td style="width: 30%; text-align: center;" rowspan="1">Succeeded&#160;by<br />
<span style="font-weight: bold"><a href="/wiki/Walter_Mondale" title="Walter Mondale">Walter Mondale</a></span><br />

<td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
<div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul>
<li><b>Incumbent nominee</b>: <b><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Barack Obama</a></b>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama_presidential_campaign,_2012" title="Barack Obama presidential campaign, 2012">campaign</a></li>

<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Political_positions_of_Joe_Biden" title="Political positions of Joe Biden">positions</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>

<tr>
<th scope="row" class="navbox-group"><a href="/wiki/List_of_state_parties_of_the_Democratic_Party_(United_States)" title="List of state parties of the Democratic Party (United States)">State/<br />
Territorial<br />
Parties</a></th>

<tr>
<th scope="row" class="navbox-group">1901–1925</th>
<td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
<div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1901</span> <a href="/wiki/Henry_Dunant" title="Henry Dunant">Henry Dunant</a>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric_Passy" title="Frédéric Passy">Frédéric Passy</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1902</span> <a href="/wiki/%C3%89lie_Ducommun" title="Élie Ducommun">Élie Ducommun</a>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/Charles_Albert_Gobat" title="Charles Albert Gobat">Charles Gobat</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1903</span> <a href="/wiki/Randal_Cremer" title="Randal Cremer">Randal Cremer</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1904</span> <a href="/wiki/Institut_de_Droit_International" title="Institut de Droit International">Institut de Droit International</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1905</span> <a href="/wiki/Bertha_von_Suttner" title="Bertha von Suttner">Bertha von Suttner</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1906</span> <a href="/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt" title="Theodore Roosevelt">Theodore Roosevelt</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1907</span> <a href="/wiki/Ernesto_Teodoro_Moneta" title="Ernesto Teodoro Moneta">Ernesto Moneta</a>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/Louis_Renault_(jurist)" title="Louis Renault (jurist)">Louis Renault</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1908</span> <a href="/wiki/Klas_Pontus_Arnoldson" title="Klas Pontus Arnoldson">Klas Arnoldson</a>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/Fredrik_Bajer" title="Fredrik Bajer">Fredrik Bajer</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1909</span> <a href="/wiki/Auguste_Beernaert" title="Auguste Beernaert">A. M. F. Beernaert</a>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/Paul-Henri-Benjamin_d%27Estournelles_de_Constant" title="Paul-Henri-Benjamin d'Estournelles de Constant">Paul Estournelles de Constant</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1910</span> <a href="/wiki/International_Peace_Bureau" title="International Peace Bureau">International Peace Bureau</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1911</span> <a href="/wiki/Tobias_Asser" title="Tobias Asser">Tobias Asser</a>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Hermann_Fried" title="Alfred Hermann Fried">Alfred Fried</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1912</span> <a href="/wiki/Elihu_Root" title="Elihu Root">Elihu Root</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1913</span> <a href="/wiki/Henri_La_Fontaine" title="Henri La Fontaine">Henri La Fontaine</a></li>
<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1914</span></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1915</span></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1916</span></span></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1917</span> <a href="/wiki/International_Committee_of_the_Red_Cross" title="International Committee of the Red Cross">International Committee of the Red Cross</a></li>
<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1918</span></span></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1919</span> <a href="/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson" title="Woodrow Wilson">Woodrow Wilson</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1920</span> <a href="/wiki/L%C3%A9on_Bourgeois" title="Léon Bourgeois">Léon Bourgeois</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1921</span> <a href="/wiki/Hjalmar_Branting" title="Hjalmar Branting">Hjalmar Branting</a>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/Christian_Lous_Lange" title="Christian Lous Lange">Christian Lange</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1922</span> <a href="/wiki/Fridtjof_Nansen" title="Fridtjof Nansen">Fridtjof Nansen</a></li>
<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1923</span></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1924</span></span></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1925</span> <a href="/wiki/Austen_Chamberlain" title="Austen Chamberlain">Austen Chamberlain</a>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/Charles_G._Dawes" title="Charles G. Dawes">Charles Dawes</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</td>

<td colspan="2"></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row" class="navbox-group">1926–1950</th>
<td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
<div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1926</span> <a href="/wiki/Aristide_Briand" title="Aristide Briand">Aristide Briand</a>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/Gustav_Stresemann" title="Gustav Stresemann">Gustav Stresemann</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1927</span> <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Buisson" title="Ferdinand Buisson">Ferdinand Buisson</a>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/Ludwig_Quidde" title="Ludwig Quidde">Ludwig Quidde</a></li>
<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1928</span></span></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1929</span> <a href="/wiki/Frank_B._Kellogg" title="Frank B. Kellogg">Frank B. Kellogg</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1930</span> <a href="/wiki/Nathan_S%C3%B6derblom" title="Nathan Söderblom">Nathan Söderblom</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1931</span> <a href="/wiki/Jane_Addams" title="Jane Addams">Jane Addams</a>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Murray_Butler" title="Nicholas Murray Butler">Nicholas Butler</a></li>
<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1932</span></span></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1933</span> <a href="/wiki/Norman_Angell" title="Norman Angell">Norman Angell</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1934</span> <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Henderson" title="Arthur Henderson">Arthur Henderson</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1935</span> <a href="/wiki/Carl_von_Ossietzky" title="Carl von Ossietzky">Carl von Ossietzky</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1936</span> <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Saavedra_Lamas" title="Carlos Saavedra Lamas">Carlos Saavedra Lamas</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1937</span> <a href="/wiki/Robert_Cecil,_1st_Viscount_Cecil_of_Chelwood" title="Robert Cecil, 1st Viscount Cecil of Chelwood">Robert Cecil</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1938</span> <a href="/wiki/Nansen_International_Office_for_Refugees" title="Nansen International Office for Refugees">Nansen International Office for Refugees</a></li>
<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1939</span></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1940</span></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1941</span></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1942</span></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1943</span></span></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1944</span> <a href="/wiki/International_Committee_of_the_Red_Cross" title="International Committee of the Red Cross">International Committee of the Red Cross</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1945</span> <a href="/wiki/Cordell_Hull" title="Cordell Hull">Cordell Hull</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1946</span> <a href="/wiki/Emily_Greene_Balch" title="Emily Greene Balch">Emily Balch</a>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/John_Mott" title="John Mott">John Mott</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1947</span> <a href="/wiki/Quaker_Peace_and_Social_Witness" title="Quaker Peace and Social Witness">Friends Service Council</a>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/American_Friends_Service_Committee" title="American Friends Service Committee">American Friends Service Committee</a></li>
<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1948</span></span></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1949</span> <a href="/wiki/John_Boyd_Orr,_1st_Baron_Boyd-Orr" title="John Boyd Orr, 1st Baron Boyd-Orr">John Boyd Orr</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1950</span> <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Bunche" title="Ralph Bunche">Ralph Bunche</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</td>

<th scope="row" class="navbox-group">1951–1975</th>
<td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
<div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1951</span> <a href="/wiki/L%C3%A9on_Jouhaux" title="Léon Jouhaux">Léon Jouhaux</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1952</span> <a href="/wiki/Albert_Schweitzer" title="Albert Schweitzer">Albert Schweitzer</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1953</span> <a href="/wiki/George_Marshall" title="George Marshall">George Marshall</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1954</span> <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Refugees" title="United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees">United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees</a></li>
<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1955</span></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1956</span></span></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1957</span> <a href="/wiki/Lester_B._Pearson" title="Lester B. Pearson">Lester B. Pearson</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1958</span> <a href="/wiki/Dominique_Pire" title="Dominique Pire">Georges Pire</a></li>

<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1964</span> <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr." title="Martin Luther King Jr.">Martin Luther King Jr.</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1965</span> <a href="/wiki/UNICEF" title="UNICEF">UNICEF</a></li>

<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1967</span></span></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1968</span> <a href="/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Cassin" title="René Cassin">René Cassin</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1969</span> <a href="/wiki/International_Labour_Organization" title="International Labour Organization">International Labour Organization</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1970</span> <a href="/wiki/Norman_Borlaug" title="Norman Borlaug">Norman Borlaug</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1971</span> <a href="/wiki/Willy_Brandt" title="Willy Brandt">Willy Brandt</a></li>
<li><span style="color:darkgrey"><span style="font-size:90%;">1972</span></span></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1973</span> <i><a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_%C4%90%E1%BB%A9c_Th%E1%BB%8D" title="Lê Đức Thọ">Lê Đức Thọ</a>&#160;<small>(declined award)</small></i>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/Henry_Kissinger" title="Henry Kissinger">Henry Kissinger</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1974</span> <a href="/wiki/Se%C3%A1n_MacBride" title="Seán MacBride">Seán MacBride</a>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/Eisaku_Sat%C5%8D" title="Eisaku Satō">Eisaku Satō</a></li>
<li><span style="font-size:90%;">1975</span> <a href="/wiki/Andrei_Sakharov" title="Andrei Sakharov">Andrei Sakharov</a></li>

<li><span style="font-size:90%;">2000</span> <a href="/wiki/Kim_Dae-jung" title="Kim Dae-jung">Kim Dae-jung</a></li>

<li><span style="font-size:90%;"><a href="/wiki/2011_Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="2011 Nobel Peace Prize">2011</a></span> <a href="/wiki/Ellen_Johnson_Sirleaf" title="Ellen Johnson Sirleaf">Ellen Johnson Sirleaf</a>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/Leymah_Gbowee" title="Leymah Gbowee">Leymah Gbowee</a>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/Tawakkol_Karman" title="Tawakkol Karman">Tawakkol Karman</a></li>

<tr>
<th scope="col" class="navbox-title" colspan="3">
<div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
<ul>
<li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:United_States_Senators_from_Illinois" title="Template:United States Senators from Illinois"><abbr title="View this template" style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;">v</abbr></a></li>

<div id="Grammy_Award_for_Best_Spoken_Word_Album_.282000s.29" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Spoken_Word_Album" title="Grammy Award for Best Spoken Word Album">Grammy Award for Best Spoken Word Album</a> (2000s)</div>
</th>
</tr>
<tr style="height:2px">
<td colspan="2"></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" class="navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0px">
<div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<dl>
<dt>2000</dt>
<dd><a href="/wiki/LeVar_Burton" title="LeVar Burton">LeVar Burton</a> - <i>The Autobiography of Martin Luther King Jr.</i></dd>
<dt>2001</dt>
<dd><a href="/wiki/Sidney_Poitier" title="Sidney Poitier">Sidney Poitier</a>, Rick Harris, John Runnette (producers) - <i><a href="/wiki/The_Measure_of_a_Man:_A_Spiritual_Autobiography" title="The Measure of a Man: A Spiritual Autobiography">The Measure of a Man: A Spiritual Autobiography</a></i></dd>
<dt>2002</dt>
<dd><a href="/wiki/Quincy_Jones" title="Quincy Jones">Quincy Jones</a>, Jeffrey S. Thomas, Steven Strassman (engineers), Elisa Shokoff (producer) - <i>Q: The Autobiography of Quincy Jones</i></dd>
<dt>2003</dt>
<dd><a href="/wiki/Maya_Angelou" title="Maya Angelou">Maya Angelou</a>, Charles B. Potter (producer) - <i><a href="/wiki/A_Song_Flung_Up_to_Heaven" title="A Song Flung Up to Heaven">A Song Flung Up to Heaven</a></i> / <a href="/wiki/Robin_Williams" title="Robin Williams">Robin Williams</a>, Nathaniel Kunkel (engineer/mixer), <a href="/wiki/Peter_Asher" title="Peter Asher">Peter Asher</a> (producer) - <i><a href="/wiki/Robin_Williams:_Live_on_Broadway" class="mw-redirect" title="Robin Williams: Live on Broadway">Live 2002</a></i></dd>
<dt>2004</dt>
<dd><a href="/wiki/Al_Franken" title="Al Franken">Al Franken</a>, Paul Ruben (producer) - <i><a href="/wiki/Lies_and_the_Lying_Liars_Who_Tell_Them" title="Lies and the Lying Liars Who Tell Them">Lies and the Lying Liars Who Tell Them</a></i></dd>
<dt>2005</dt>
<dd><a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a> - <i><a href="/wiki/My_Life_(Bill_Clinton_autobiography)" title="My Life (Bill Clinton autobiography)">My Life</a></i></dd>
<dt>2006</dt>
<dd><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Barack Obama</a> - <i><a href="/wiki/Dreams_from_My_Father" title="Dreams from My Father">Dreams from My Father</a></i></dd>
<dt>2007</dt>
<dd><a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Carter" title="Jimmy Carter">Jimmy Carter</a> - <i><a href="/wiki/Our_Endangered_Values" title="Our Endangered Values">Our Endangered Values: America's Moral Crisis</a></i> / <a href="/wiki/Ossie_Davis" title="Ossie Davis">Ossie Davis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ruby_Dee" title="Ruby Dee">Ruby Dee</a> - <i>With Ossie and Ruby</i></dd>
<dt>2008</dt>
<dd><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Barack Obama</a>, Jacob Bronstein (producer) - <i><a href="/wiki/The_Audacity_of_Hope" title="The Audacity of Hope">The Audacity of Hope</a></i></dd>
<dt>2009</dt>
<dd><a href="/wiki/Beau_Bridges" title="Beau Bridges">Beau Bridges</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cynthia_Nixon" title="Cynthia Nixon">Cynthia Nixon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Blair_Underwood" title="Blair Underwood">Blair Underwood</a> - <i><a href="/wiki/An_Inconvenient_Truth_(book)" title="An Inconvenient Truth (book)">An Inconvenient Truth</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Al_Gore" title="Al Gore">Al Gore</a></dd>
</dl>
</div>
</td>

                <div class="fig-graphic ">

        <div class="summary">
            <header>
                <h3>
                    <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2017/05/25/how-obama-undercuts-trump-238814" target="_top">How Obama not so subtly undercuts Trump</a></h3>
                </header>

                               <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2017/05/30/trump-europe-germany-paris-238952" target="_top"><img data-lazy-img="http://static.politico.com/dims4/default/bfae01e/2147483647/legacy_thumbnail/266x150%5E/quality/90/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fstatic.politico.com%2Fe8%2Fd0%2F1fcd7b9a4a6bb602983f33c38d37%2F170530-trump-nato-gty-1160.jpg" width="266" height="150" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==" data-size="promo_small_rectangle"></a></div>
                       <ol class="story-frag-list layout-linear ">

                            <li>
                                    <article class="story-frag format-xxs">
                                                <div class="summary">
                                                    <header>
                                                        <h3><a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2017/05/30/trump-europe-germany-paris-238952" target="_top">White House to Europe: Trump picks on you because he likes you</a></h3>
                                                    </header>
                                                </div>
                                            </article>
                                        </li>
                            </ol>
                    </div>

                    </div></div>
</aside>
</section>

</div>
        </div>
    </div>

    </main>

ng-class="pageClasses"><script type="application/json" id="pageItemData">{"quotes":["I am not opposed to all wars. I'm opposed to dumb wars.","Our challenges may be new, the instruments with which we meet them may be new, but those values upon which our success depends, honesty and hard work, courage and fair play, tolerance and curiosity, loyalty and patriotism -- these things are old.","We, the People, recognize that we have responsibilities as well as rights; that our destinies are bound together; that a freedom which only asks what&rsquo;s in it for me, a freedom without a commitment to others, a freedom without love or charity or duty or patriotism, is unworthy of our founding ideals, and those who died in their defense.","Our government should work for us, not against us. It should help us, not hurt us. It should ensure opportunity not just for those with the most money and influence, but for every American who's willing to work.","No single individual built America on their own. We built it together. We have been, and always will be, one nation, under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all; a nation with responsibilities to ourselves and with responsibilities to one another.","We are a nation that endures because of the courage of those who defend it.","So don't let anyone tell you that change is not possible. Don't let them tell you that standing out and speaking up about injustice is too risky. What's too risky is keeping quiet. What's too risky is looking the other way.","Our journey is not complete until our gay brothers and sisters are treated like anyone else under the law--for if we are truly created equal, then surely the love we commit to one another must be equal as well.","I have always believed that hope is that stubborn thing inside us that insists, despite all the evidence to the contrary, that something better awaits us so long as we have the courage to keep reaching, to keep working, to keep fighting.","It is easier to start wars than to end them.","I guarantee you we will move this country forward. We will finish what we started. And we'll remind the world just why it is the United States of America is the greatest nation on Earth.","We don't quit. I don't quit. Let's seize this moment to start anew, to carry the dream forward, and strengthen our union once more.","It's only when you hitch your wagon to something larger than yourself that you will realize your true potential.","What Washington needs is adult supervision.","If you're walking down the right path and you're willing to keep walking, eventually you'll make progress.","My job is not to represent Washington to you, but to represent you to Washington.","Change will not come if we wait for some other person or some other time. We are the ones we've been waiting for. We are the change that we seek.","Hope&mdash;Hope in the face of difficulty. Hope in the face of uncertainty. The audacity of hope! In the end, that is God's greatest gift to us, the bedrock of this nation.","If we aren't willing to pay a price for our values, then we should ask ourselves whether we truly believe in them at all.","Yes, we can. Yes, we can change. Yes, we can.","And where we are met with cynicism and doubt and fear ... we will respond with that timeless creed that sums up the spirit of the American people in three simple words&mdash;yes, we Alumni.","id":"ci019b6c01f93f860d","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"Harvard Law School","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":4992,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396404160,"id":"ci01a8bfd5f33d860b","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"William-Joseph-Jr-Brennan-9225272-1-raw","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a8bfd5f33d860b","hasFaces":true,"width":3377,"publicId":"MTE5NTU2MzE1NzU1MDIxODM1","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T02:02:43Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":4890681,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:schools","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T06:04:43Z","disqusId":"e11a3386-ba0a-11e3-a891-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T01:59:51Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T06:04:43Z","versionId":"3","primaryImageId":"ci01a8bfd5f33d860b","path":"/people/groups/famous-alumni-of-harvard-law-school","isWorkInProgress":false,"overviewTml":"<!-- Law.<\/p><p><\/p>\n","slug":"famous-alumni-of-harvard-law-school","displayName":"Harvard Law School","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","teaser":"Meet famous people who attended Harvard
